title: A molecular epidemiological approach to combat footrot an epidemic disease of sheep host and pathogen perspectives from India and GB
abstractText: Abstracts are not currently available in GtR for all funded research. This is normally because the abstract was not required at the time of proposal submission, but may be because it included sensitive information such as personal details.
impactText:
Two key impacts arose from the Partnering India award. First a clinic trial was run in India and results from this have been presented to farmers in India and the UK in talks as part of knowledge exchange on management of footrot in sheep.
Second an MSc student that we met on our visit to India discussed the possibility of a PhD at Warwick. He applied to our Chancellor's scholarship award scheme and was successful. He si currently in the final year of his PhD. Agriculture, Food and Drink Cultural,Societal,Economic
findingsText:
The level of lameness in sheep is high in north India and farmers are unsure of how to treat sheep lame with footrot. Footrot is though to contribute to poor fertility because sheep are in poor body condition. Treatment with antibiotics led to recovery from lameness, even in sheep that had been lame for 2 years. 
Collaboration through this partnering award led to an Indian veterinary scientist taking a PhD at Warwick. By raising the profile of the research in India there have been collaborations between Srinagar, India, Warwick and Monash, Australia on the pathogen that causes footrot in sheep.
